posts.cooked:
Hey all,

I have a question about account ID‚Äôs and all that.

I‚Äôm aware that Signal can see the phone number of an account from a @username, but only while it‚Äôs active. However, I have read some people online saying it‚Äôs possible to Signal to see the phone number of an account in some circumstances without the @username and I‚Äôm trying to figure out what‚Äôs true or not.

Basically, I want to have a public group that people can join with a link I would like to know if Signal could be coerced into handing over the phone numbers from that public group (admins or otherwise) while it is active, with the invite link to the group.

Thank you!

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Can Signal See Phone Numbers of Public Group Admins?

no.

Signal Messenger

Government Communication

When legally forced to provide information to government or law enforcement agencies, we'll disclose the transcripts of that communication here.

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
rassilon1963:

When legally forced to provide information to government or law enforcement agencies, we‚Äôll disclose the transcripts of that communication here.

Yeah well, in the US that is a useless statement because of the usual gag orders given in such cases. A warrant canary is slightly better because US law does not allow forced speech, so it can‚Äôt be forced to be upgraded while untrue. But I‚Äôm not sure if the US government has already found a way around that.

anon53652:

A warrant canary is slightly better because US law does not allow forced speech, so it can‚Äôt be forced to be upgraded while untrue. But I‚Äôm not sure if the US government has already found a way around that.

posts.cooked: not for group admins and yes for a single username? are you sure?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Given a phone number the server cannot tell what username it‚Äôs connected to (though it can know that number has one).
Given an active username however, the server can give back a number.
https://signal.miraheze.org/wiki/Usernames#Privacy
you need to have the full username including discriminator though, and it has to be in use at time of query.

rassilon1963:

it has to be in use at time of query.

what this does mean?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
it means that if you switch to a different username, the old one would be useless for an attacker thereafter.
so if on January 1st Big Brother discovers that the username abc.123 is in use, then on January 2nd i switch to def.456, then on January 3rd they get a warrant and knock on Signal‚Äôs doors asking who‚Äôs abc.123, Signal wouldn‚Äôt be able to help them.
now it‚Äôs more clear. And what if I keep the same username but change just the discriminator?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
then it‚Äôs a different username. since it‚Äôs the hash that‚Äôs used to connect a username to an account, two usernames with different discriminators are to the server wholly unrelated, even if the nicknames (that‚Äôs what the non-discriminator part is called) are the same.
of course that new username would be easier for Big Brother to guess, but that‚Äôs not really a technical issue with usernames.

rassilon1963:

Given an active username however, the server can give back a number.

aren‚Äôt the phone numbers hashed on the server? how can the server decrypt a hash?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i‚Äôm virtually not at all familiar with server code so i can only rely on other sources. this comment says that it‚Äôs possible (and it‚Äôs also linked as a source in the wiki article linked above for the same reason).
Signal is doing some server work as of late to reduce the prevalence of phone numbers use, so it‚Äôs possible this fact has changed since, but with no clear info stating otherwise, one shoudl assume that it still holds.

link_counts.title: Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 7.0 release

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
signalOne:

aren‚Äôt the phone numbers hashed on the server? how can the server decrypt a hash?

That‚Äôs easy: the space of available valid phone numbers is so small that it can be brute-forced.
Thank you. I had seen some people saying signal can still see an ‚Äúaccount ID‚Äù which it can then link to a phone number, but I never saw anything confirming it. Must be FUD or misunderstanding.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
this is definitely not true thanks to Sealed Sender.

Signal Messenger

Technology preview: Sealed sender for Signal

In addition to the end-to-end encryption that protects every Signal message, the Signal service is designed to minimize the data that is retained about Signal users. By design, it does not store a record of your contacts, social graph, conversation...

and even had it not been a thing, there‚Äôs still not a way to distinguish between DMs and group messages without access to some keys.

link_counts.title: Signal >> Blog >> Technology preview: Sealed sender for Signal

posts.cooked:
In any case, if signal (or anyone else) is given the link to a public group, they can join that group an see who is in it. I guess this isn‚Äôt as bad as i could be because of phone number privacy, wich prevents group members from seeing the phone numbers. But you could see the members profiles, names, info and profile picture. That could also be of interest to law enforcement.

I belive it could also help if the group is invite only, but not sure.

But this is a case of: when its a public group, everyone can see its contents and members
